title: COVID-GRAM Critical Illness Risk Score
desc: The COVID-GRAM Critical Illness Risk Score predicts risk of critical illness in hospitalized COVID-19 patients.

orgreference.text: Liang W, Liang H, Ou L, et al. Development and Validation of a Clinical Risk Score to Predict the Occurrence of Critical Illness in Hospitalized Patients With COVID-19. JAMA Intern Med. 2020.

data.evidence:
COVID-GRAM Risk Score = (X-ray abnormality x 27.1464) + (Age x 0.6139) + (Hemoptysis x 33.6210) + (Dyspnea x 14.0569) + (Unconsciousness x 34.4617) + (Number of comorbidities x 10.3826) + (Cancer history x 31.2211) + (Neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio x 1.25) + (Lactate dehydrogenase x 0.0534) + (Direct bilirubin x 3.0605), where variables are as follows: 

Variable

Points

X-ray abnormality

 Yes

1
No

0
Age, years

Continuous
Hemoptysis Yes

No

0

No

0

Continuous
Cancer history Yes

1
No

0
Neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio

Continuous
Lactate dehydrogenase, U/L

Continuous
Direct bilirubin, μmol/L

Continuous

*Includes COPD, hypertension, diabetes, coronary heart disease, chronic heart disease, chronic kidney disease, cancer, cerebral vascular disease, Hepatitis B, and immunodeficiency.
data.facts:
Risk of critical illness†, % = ex / (1 + ex),

Where x = (X-ray abnormality x 1.2205) + (Age x 0.0276) + (Hemoptysis  x 1.5116) + (Dyspnea x 0.632) + (Unconsciousness x 1.5494) + (Number of comorbidities x 0.4668) + (Cancer history x 1.4037) + (Neutrophil to lymphocyte ratio x 0.0562) + (Lactate dehydrogenase x 0.0024) + (Direct bilirubin x 0.1376) - 6.6127 and variables are as listed in the table above.  

†Defined by admission to the intensive care unit (ICU), invasive ventilation, or death.

Interpretation:

Risk of critical illness

 Risk group

<1.7%

 Low

1.7% to <40.4%

 Medium

≥40.4%

 High

estimation.name: Upper Limit of Normal Serum LDH

inputs.name: comorbid
inputs.tips_en: Includes COPD, hypertension, diabetes, coronary heart disease, chronic heart disease, chronic kidney disease, cancer, cerebral vascular disease, Hepatitis B, and immunodeficiency
